solution_line_template: Jill's second customer buys {second_customer_multiplier} times more than her first customer's {first_customer_boxes} boxes, so they buy {second_customer_multiplier}*{first_customer_boxes}=<<{second_customer_multiplier}*{first_customer_boxes}={second_customer_boxes}>>{second_customer_boxes} boxes

Jill's third customer buys half of what her second customer bought, so that means they buy {second_customer_boxes}/{third_customer_divisor}= <<{second_customer_boxes}/{third_customer_divisor}={third_customer_boxes}>>{third_customer_boxes} boxes

Jill's fourth customer buys {fourth_customer_multiplier} times as many as what her third customer bought, so that means they buy {third_customer_boxes}*{fourth_customer_multiplier}= <<{fourth_customer_multiplier}*{third_customer_boxes}={fourth_customer_boxes}>>{fourth_customer_boxes} boxes

Adding in the {first_customer_boxes} boxes sold to the first customer, and the {final_customer_boxes} boxes sold to the last one, that means Jill has sold {first_customer_boxes}+{final_customer_boxes}+{second_customer_boxes}+{third_customer_boxes}+{fourth_customer_boxes}= <<{first_customer_boxes}+{final_customer_boxes}+{second_customer_boxes}+{third_customer_boxes}+{fourth_customer_boxes}={total_boxes_sold}>>{total_boxes_sold} boxes

Since Jill's goal is {sales_goal} boxes sold, and she's only sold {total_boxes_sold} so far, she needs to sell {sales_goal}-{total_boxes_sold}=<<{sales_goal}-{total_boxes_sold}={boxes_left_to_sell}>>{boxes_left_to_sell} more boxes to hit her goal
